study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bobath therapy improves lower limb activity performance, strength, or coordination in adults with stroke compared to other interventions or no intervention.
results_summary: The study found that Bobath therapy was inferior to task-specific training for improving lower limb activities and not superior to other interventions, except for proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation, where it showed better results for standing balance. No clear benefits were observed for strength or coordination compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Adults after stroke

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and feasibility of combining exercise (walking and resistance training) with resveratrol to improve physical function and skeletal muscle mitochondrial function in older adults with functional limitations.
results_summary: The study found that combining exercise with resveratrol was safe and feasible, with potential improvements in skeletal muscle mitochondrial function and mobility-related physical function, particularly in the six-minute walk test. Adverse events were similar across groups, and adherence to the exercise and supplement protocols was high.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (mean age 71.8 ± 6.3 years) with functional limitations.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/day or 1000 mg/day resveratrol, alongside twice-weekly exercise sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding motivational interviewing to a physical activity monitor (PAM)-based intervention could enhance physical activity levels, particularly walking, in older adults.
results_summary: The study expected a moderate increase in daily physical activity (measured via steps) when motivational interviewing was combined with PAMs, compared to PAMs alone. Secondary outcomes included improvements in health-related quality of life, self-efficacy, and social relations.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of HTLV-1 infection and its associated neurological disease (HAM/TSP) on quality of life, comparing those who are wheelchair-dependent versus those still walking unaided.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with HAM/TSP who were wheelchair-dependent had the lowest quality of life, while those still walking unaided had the highest. Asymptomatic carriers also reported impaired quality of life compared to the general population.
population_specificity: 141 individuals infected with HTLV-1 (79 with HAM/TSP and 62 asymptomatic carriers) from Brazil and the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of low-frequency pelvic somatic nerve stimulation on standing and walking recovery in patients with chronic spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: Most patients (71.4%) regained voluntary knee extension, and 92.8% could stand with stimulation. Over two-thirds (67.8%) could walk >10 meters, with some requiring assistive devices. Notably, 68% of complete motor SCI patients achieved voluntary walking.
population_specificity: 29 patients with chronic spinal cord injuries (paraplegia, tetraplegia, complete/incomplete SCI, flaccid/spastic paralysis).
effective_dosage: Continuous low-frequency pelvic lumbosacral nerve neuromodulation (specific parameters not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up over 9 years (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of pentoxifylline in improving walking capacity (pain-free and total walking distance) in people with stable intermittent claudication, Fontaine stage II.
results_summary: The review found low-certainty evidence that pentoxifylline may improve pain-free and total walking distance compared to placebo, but no evidence of benefit to ankle-brachial pressure index or quality of life. Pentoxifylline was generally well tolerated, with gastrointestinal symptoms being the most common side effects.
population_specificity: People with stable intermittent claudication, Fontaine stage II (peripheral arterial disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the measurement properties, strengths, and limitations of fixed-distance walk tests (≤ 40 meters) in adults with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that fixed-distance walk tests (≤ 40 meters) demonstrated good reliability and validity across different protocols (fast- or self-paced). Clinicians and researchers can safely use these tests with practice trials to acclimatize patients.
population_specificity: Adults with knee osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate contextual factors, implementation outcomes, and student outcomes in existing walking school bus programs to inform large-scale implementation.
results_summary: Walking school bus programs in low-income communities had more route leaders and greater sustainability. Programs with no external funding, multiple route leaders, and school/district coordination had higher student participation. More weekly trips were associated with reduced tardiness, bullying, and improved neighborhood walkability.
population_specificity: Children participating in walking school bus programs in the United States and internationally.

study_goal: To develop a predictive model of neuromuscular hip dysplasia (NHD) in teenagers with cerebral palsy (CP) to optimize rehabilitation, focusing on factors affecting walking abilities.
results_summary: Poor walking abilities were associated with trunk muscle tone disorder, severe scoliosis, epilepsy, and spasticity, which were predictors of NHD in teenagers with CP. Preventative rehabilitation interventions were developed based on these findings.
population_specificity: Teenagers with cerebral palsy (age 16.5 ± 1.2 years, range 12-18 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review surgical treatments for scrotal laxity and penoscrotal webbing, proposing a diagnostic and therapeutic approach.
results_summary: The study identified 11 eligible articles, mostly case reports or surgical technique descriptions, and proposed a vertical midline scrotal skin resection and penoscrotal junction Z plasty for correction.
population_specificity: Individuals with scrotal laxity or penoscrotal webbing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in willingness to undergo joint surgery after a first-line intervention involving education and exercise for individuals with knee or hip osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that a first-line intervention reduced willingness to undergo surgery, particularly among knee OA patients (45% became unwilling after 3 months, 35% after 12 months). High pain intensity, walking difficulties, and fear of movement were linked to higher odds of surgery willingness, while increased self-efficacy showed the opposite association.
population_specificity: 30,578 individuals with knee or hip OA participating in a first-line intervention in Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a clinical and psychosocial profile could predict adherence to walking in women with fibromyalgia and severe pain.
results_summary: Patients who walked regularly despite pain showed significantly lower FM impact, anxiety, depression, catastrophizing, cognitive fusion, and negative affect. FM impact and negative affect were the unique predictors of walking adherence.
population_specificity: 172 women with fibromyalgia and severe pain (>7 on an 11-point scale).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a customized three-dimensional printed tantalum implant for reconstructing a massive pelvic bone defect and enabling functional recovery, including walking, after tumor removal.
results_summary: The patient successfully walked one month post-surgery with no tumor recurrence, implant failure, or complications during the 12-month follow-up, demonstrating satisfactory functional recovery.
population_specificity: A 30-year-old woman with a massive low-grade chondrosarcoma in the pelvic bone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore changes in genome-wide DNA methylation after a 6-week exercise intervention, including walking, in colorectal cancer survivors.
results_summary: The exercise group showed notable methylation changes in 756 CpG sites, with genes linked to immune response, transcription, and disease prevention showing altered methylation patterns compared to controls. Hypermethylation on disease prevention-related genes appeared inhibited, suggesting potential transcriptional activity.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer survivors (n=15, subset analyzed n=8)
effective_dosage: Weekly supervised resistance exercise plus home-based resistance exercise and walking six times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mulligan's mobilization with movement (MWM) improves knee joint kinematics, pain, walking speed, and functional mobility in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison between standard rehabilitation and rehabilitation augmented with MWM, but results are not yet available as it describes a planned trial. Outcomes will include knee range of motion, pain, walking speed, and functional mobility.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (articular mobilization using MWM approach).
study_duration: Intervention administered from 3 to 6 weeks post-operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of MERS presenting with bilateral transient blindness and difficulty in walking, highlighting an unusual symptom of the condition.
results_summary: The study found that a 4-year-old child with MERS experienced transient bilateral blindness and walking difficulty, which resolved after treatment with corticosteroids and antiviral therapy. Brain MRI showed reversible lesions in the splenium of the corpus callosum, and symptoms fully resolved within 40 days.
population_specificity: 4-year-old female patient with MERS.
effective_dosage: Not specified (empiric antiviral treatment with acyclovir and intravenous dexamethasone, followed by oral corticosteroids).
study_duration: 10 days of treatment, with follow-up after 40 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of active complementary and integrative health interventions (including Tai Chi, Pilates, yoga, and qigong) for adults post-stroke.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi, Pilates, and yoga improved various physical and emotional health outcomes in post-stroke adults, with Tai Chi showing the strongest evidence. No specific results were reported for Walking.
population_specificity: Adults post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if inducing a weight shift to the affected side by raising the shoe height of the less affected side during treadmill training improves gait ability in people with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill training with an insole on the less affected side (ILTW) significantly improved multiple gait parameters (e.g., speed, stride length, support duration) and functional walking tests (FGA, F8WT, 6MWT) compared to normal treadmill training (NTW). The ILTW group showed broader improvements than the NTW group, suggesting enhanced walking ability in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: People with chronic stroke
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 5 times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Qishen Yiqi Drop Pill (QSYQ) combined with Western therapy for congestive heart failure (CHF) patients using a meta-analysis approach.
results_summary: The meta-analysis indicated that QSYQ combined with Western therapy might be effective in CHF patients, though further research is needed to identify optimal patient subgroups and combination treatments.
population_specificity: Congestive heart failure (CHF) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare plantar pressure variables (heel, arch, forefoot) during exercise on four elliptical machines versus walking.
results_summary: Plantar pressures were generally lower on ellipticals compared to walking, with variations observed between different elliptical models, particularly under the heel.
population_specificity: Ten young adults.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of exercise, including walking, on physical outcomes in breast cancer survivors receiving hormone therapy.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic plus resistance exercise, including walking, improved cardiorespiratory fitness and pain in breast cancer survivors on hormone therapy, but no significant effects were observed for other physical outcomes like bone mineral density or grip strength.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors receiving hormone therapy (tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of step-count monitors on physical activity in community-dwelling adults, comparing different types of monitors and intervention components.
results_summary: Step-count monitoring significantly increased walking, with effects lasting up to 3-4 years. Pedometers were more effective than body-worn trackers or smartphone apps, and additional counseling/incentives did not enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults, including healthy individuals and those at risk of disease.
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from ≤4 months to 3-4 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new evaluation system to assess the severity of clubfoot deformity in untreated or conservatively managed walking children.
results_summary: The study found correlations between various anatomical measurements (e.g., Talocalcaneal index, Tibiocalcaneal angle) and specific deformities (equinus, varus), leading to a new classification system for severity assessment.
population_specificity: Children aged 1-5 years with unilateral clubfoot, previously managed conservatively, excluding atypical or surgically intervened cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify preoperative characteristics in intermediately frail and frail colorectal cancer patients who could not attain a 400m 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) before surgery and assess its impact on postoperative complications.
results_summary: 60% of prehabilitated patients failed to reach 400m 6MWD pre-surgery; this group had higher complication rates (61% vs. 21%) and poorer baseline health metrics compared to those who achieved ≥400m. The study suggests 400m 6MWD as a potential minimal target for prehabilitation.
population_specificity: Intermediately frail and frail (Fried frailty criteria ≥2) elective colorectal cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a progressive and individualized walking and education program for preventing recurrences of low back pain in adults.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it compares a walking and education intervention with a no-treatment control group, measuring time to recurrence of low back pain, disability, quality of life, and associated costs over 12 months.
population_specificity: Adults who have recovered from an episode of non-specific low back pain within the last 6 months.
effective_dosage: Six sessions (three face-to-face and three telephone-delivered) with a physiotherapist over 6 months to facilitate a progressive walking program and education.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, feasibility, and potential benefits of training with the Myosuit wearable robot for individuals with motor disorders to improve walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that training with the Myosuit was safe and feasible, with no adverse events reported. Five out of eight participants who completed the study showed improved walking speed when using the device.
population_specificity: Individuals with diverse motor disorders who could walk at least 10 meters.
effective_dosage: Five training sessions with a net training time of 45 minutes each.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be short-term (five sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of activities, including walking, conducted outside residential aged care settings on people with dementia.
results_summary: The study found preliminary evidence of psychological, physical, and physiological benefits from walking and other out-of-care activities for people with dementia, though generalizability was limited by small sample sizes and lack of control groups in most studies.
population_specificity: People with dementia living in residential aged care facilities.
study_duration: Ranged from 3 weeks to 5 months across studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a 12-week exercise-based intervention, including a home-based walking program, on physical function and other outcomes in older women (≥65 years) with breast cancer receiving systemic therapy.
results_summary: The study assessed physical function and secondary outcomes like feasibility, functional measures, symptom burden, and quality of life, but specific results regarding walking's effects are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older women (≥65 years) with breast cancer receiving (neo)adjuvant or first-line or second-line systemic therapy.
effective_dosage: Home-based walking program based on daily step counts (specific step count not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a group-delivered spasticity self-management program (STC) with stretching exercises compared to a control program on the impact and severity of spasticity in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The pilot trial suggested that the STC program, which included education and stretching, showed promising effects on reducing the impact of spasticity and improving self-report and physical performance measures, including walking. A larger, fully-powered trial is planned to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults with MS who self-reported spasticity interfering with daily activities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included daily stretching exercises).
study_duration: One month of home stretching practice post-intervention, with follow-ups at one and six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how vision enhancements via head-mounted displays (HMDs) improve mobility, orientation, and visual function in people with low vision.
results_summary: Vision enhancements simplified scenes, improving obstacle detection and object recognition but reducing walking speed. Minification expanded the visual field but lacked extensive mobility studies, and commercial devices underperformed compared to conventional aids.
population_specificity: People with low vision

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sensitivity of specific situations to provoke freezing of gait (FOG) in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and compare the effects of l-dopa and subthalamic nucleus deep brain stimulation (STN-DBS) on FOG severity.
results_summary: Turning was the most sensitive provoking situation for FOG. Both l-dopa and STN-DBS similarly improved all FOG subtypes, with a stronger combined effect on FOG severity. A carry-over effect of STN-DBS was observed, reducing FOG severity at follow-up compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 124 Parkinson's disease patients with positive FOG according to the Unified Parkinson Rating Scale part II item 14.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical outcomes of endoscopic lesser trochanter resection via a posterior approach in patients with Ischiofemoral impingement.
results_summary: The study found that endoscopic resection improved function, as shown by higher modified Harris Hip Scores, and achieved pain relief in most patients. Three complications were reported, including two requiring revision surgery.
population_specificity: 13 patients (16 hips) with Ischiofemoral impingement, mean age 34.4 years, predominantly women (11/13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether social engagement and social comparisons could increase physical activity (walking) among older adults.
results_summary: Participants in the experimental condition significantly increased their mean weekly steps and social engagement compared to the control group, with effects maintained at the 1-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age = 65.7, N = 60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a home-based physical training and activity promotion program, including strength, balance, and walking training, on life-space mobility (LSM) in older persons with cognitive impairment (CI) after discharge from rehabilitation.
results_summary: The home-based training program significantly improved LSM composite scores and independent life-space subscores in the intervention group compared to the control group, though effects were not sustained during the follow-up period. Other subscores did not show significant differences.
population_specificity: Older persons (mean age 82.3 ± 6.0 years) with mild-to-moderate cognitive impairment (Mini-Mental State Examination: 23.3 ± 2.4) discharged home from geriatric rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of descending (DSE) and ascending (ASE) stair walking on body composition, insulin sensitivity, and inflammatory markers in young Chinese women with obesity.
results_summary: Both DSE and ASE improved body composition and reduced pro-inflammatory markers, with DSE showing superior improvements in insulin sensitivity and abdominal fat reduction. TNF-α levels decreased significantly more in the DSE group compared to ASE and control groups.
population_specificity: Young Chinese women with obesity.
effective_dosage: Three sessions of stair walking per week, with gradual increase in repetitions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the distribution, determinants, and predictors of physical activity levels, particularly walking, in older hospitalized patients using wrist-worn accelerometers.
results_summary: Older hospitalized patients were physically active only 10% of daily time, with activity concentrated around eating periods. Active patients had lower dependency levels and reduced use of walking aids or medical equipment.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) hospitalized with acute medical illness, able to walk prior to admission.
study_duration: During acute hospital stay (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fall prevention exercise on outdoor multisurface terrain was more beneficial for older adults compared to indoor solid ground.
results_summary: The study compared walking on outdoor multisurface terrain versus indoor solid ground for fall prevention in older adults, but the abstract does not provide specific results.
population_specificity: Older nursing home residents (n=22)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on walking as a therapeutic tool for people with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and provide evidence-based clinical recommendations for its use.
results_summary: Regular walking, especially when supervised, improves glucose control, cardiorespiratory fitness, body weight, and blood pressure in T2DM patients. Short bouts of walking to break prolonged sitting also improve glucose profiles in sedentary diabetic patients.
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and feasibility of autologous adipose-derived regenerative cell (ADRC) implantation for therapeutic angiogenesis in patients with critical limb ischaemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found no adverse events related to the ADRC procedure, no major limb amputations, and partial or complete healing of ischemic ulcers. Clinical improvements were observed in rest pain and 6-minute walking distance.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischaemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pro-kin visual feedback balance training, combined with conventional training, improves walking and self-care abilities in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking ability (measured by the Holden Walking Ability Scale and FAC) and self-care abilities (measured by the Barthel Index) in stroke patients after 3 weeks of training, with the treatment group outperforming the control group.
population_specificity: 40 stroke patients (20 in the control group, 20 in the treatment group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (conventional balance training + Pro-kin visual feedback balance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and biomechanical effects of using trekking poles during hiking or Nordic walking and discuss their clinical implications.
results_summary: Trekking poles reduce lower extremity loading and forces but increase cardiovascular demand during unloaded walking. When carrying heavy loads, they decrease lower extremity muscle activity and improve balance and stability.
population_specificity: Hikers and Nordic walkers (general population, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether counseling by a computer-based virtual advisor was noninferior to human advisors for increasing 12-month walking levels among inactive adults.
results_summary: The study found that virtual advisor counseling produced significant 12-month walking increases (153.9 min/wk) comparable to human advisors (131.9 min/wk), supporting noninferiority. Both interventions improved clinical risk factors, sedentary behavior, and well-being measures.
population_specificity: Inactive adults aged 50+ (mean age 62.3), primarily Latino (98.4%), with a mean BMI of 32.8, from community centers in California.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of stiff-person syndrome (SPS) triggered by insulin injections in a patient with latent autoimmune diabetes, highlighting its impact on walking difficulty.
results_summary: The study found that subcutaneous insulin injections precipitated abdominal stiffness and painful muscle spasms, leading to walking difficulty in a patient with latent autoimmune diabetes. Splitting the basal insulin dosage into two daily injections reduced muscle rigidity and improved glucose control without diabetic ketoacidosis.
population_specificity: A 43-year-old man with latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA).
effective_dosage: Basal insulin split into two separate daily injections with lower units per injection (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: Insulin therapy was administered over two months initially, then resumed after 10 years of oral anti-diabetic treatment (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the additive effects of exercise and essential amino acid supplementation on muscle mass, strength, and walking ability in older Japanese women with muscle mass decline.
results_summary: The study found no significant additive effects of amino acid supplementation combined with exercise on muscle mass or strength, but it did observe a beneficial effect on low back discomfort in the exercise + amino acid group.
population_specificity: Older Japanese women (over 65 years) with muscle mass decline but without weakness and slowness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a home-based graduated walking program versus a fixed walking recommendation on fatigue in older women with breast cancer undergoing radiation therapy.
results_summary: Both walking interventions increased physical activity and improved physical function, but neither significantly reduced fatigue more than the other. However, increased walking over time was associated with lower fatigue levels.
population_specificity: Women aged 65+ with stage 0-3 breast cancer undergoing adjuvant radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Mean walking increased from 21 min/week at baseline to 83 min/week by the end of RT.
study_duration: Duration of radiation therapy (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a microprocessor-controlled orthosis (MPO) improves balance, mobility, and quality of life in individuals with lower-extremity impairments compared to other orthoses.
results_summary: The MPO significantly improved gait speed, balance, functional mobility, and quality of life compared to baseline and stance-control orthoses, with fewer reported falls. Participants also walked longer distances during the 6-minute walk test with the MPO.
population_specificity: 18 community-dwelling adults with lower-extremity impairments due to neurologic, neuromuscular, orthopedic, or traumatic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBaP) versus biventricular pacing (Bi-V) in heart failure patients with left bundle branch block (LBBB).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking, as the study focuses on pacing methods (LBBaP vs. Bi-V) and their effects on cardiac outcomes.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF ≤35%) and left bundle branch block (LBBB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the treatment effects of Motor Imagery (MI) on improving walking ability in individuals after stroke.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that MI may improve walking speed compared to other therapies, but no significant benefits were observed for motor function or functional mobility. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Individuals in acute, subacute, or chronic stages of stroke with gait deficits, aged 50-78 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether proper hydration and albumin supplementation could improve symptoms and functional outcomes in patients with severe intermittent claudication or rest pain due to peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that compliant patients showed significant improvements in ankle-brachial index, skin temperature, and walking distance, with sustained benefits observed over 6 months. Noncompliant patients showed no improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with severe intermittent claudication or rest pain (132 participants, 94 male, 38 female, median age 72.5 years).
effective_dosage: 2500 mL of fluids daily (water, soup, milk) and 0.6 g/kg of albumin per day (as egg white or powder).
study_duration: 6 months (with indefinite continuation for some patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sonodynamic therapy (SDT) could reduce plaque inflammation and improve walking performance in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: SDT significantly reduced plaque inflammation, increased peak walking time, improved ankle-brachial index, decreased lesional stenosis, and enhanced quality-of-life walking metrics compared to the control group, with effects sustained for up to 6 months.
population_specificity: 32 participants (mean age 64.7 years, 63% male) with symptomatic femoropopliteal PAD.
study_duration: 30-day primary outcome assessment, with follow-up up to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if acutely manipulating peak vertical ground reaction force (vGRF) during gait influences acute changes in serum cartilage oligomeric matrix protein concentration (sCOMP) among individuals with anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR).
results_summary: The study found no difference in sCOMP change across loading conditions for the entire cohort. However, within a subgroup that naturally showed an increase in sCOMP after walking, high and symmetric loading conditions resulted in lower sCOMP changes compared to the control condition.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals with unilateral ACLR (70% female, mean age 20.43 ± 2.91 years, mean BMI 24.42 ± 4.25, mean time post-ACLR 47.83 ± 26.97 months).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of walking under different loading conditions (control, symmetric, high, and low vGRF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sitting and lying Liuzijue (a form of exercise) on lung function, exercise endurance, and quality of life in AECOPD patients with non-invasive ventilation.
results_summary: The study assessed pulmonary function, 6-minute walking test, blood gas parameters, dyspnea, BODE index, anxiety, depression, and quality of life, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: AECOPD patients with non-invasive ventilation (64 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of early versus late rehabilitation (specifically walking) on physical function recovery in older patients hospitalized for acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF).
results_summary: Early rehabilitation (initiated within 72 hours of admission) was associated with a significantly higher rate of unassisted walking by 30 days compared to late rehabilitation, with a hazard ratio of 8.03 in the adjusted model. The findings were consistent in multiple imputation analysis.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) hospitalized for ADHF who underwent inpatient rehabilitation.
study_duration: Intervention timing (early vs. late rehabilitation) was measured, but total duration of rehabilitation was not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nurse-led outdoor group walking program in reducing cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in individuals with moderate CVD risk.
results_summary: The 12-week nurse-led outdoor group walking program significantly reduced systolic blood pressure and cholesterol levels, leading to a significant decrease in CVD risk levels. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals with moderate cardiovascular risk.
effective_dosage: Outdoor group walking 5 days a week, each session lasting 40 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness of bipedal hopping as a novel outcome measure to detect subtle sensorimotor impairments in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) who show no clinical deficits during walking.
results_summary: Bipedal hopping effectively measures power, coordination, balance, and muscle timing, exposing sensorimotor impairments not apparent during walking. The test can differentiate types of impairments through variables like hop length, symmetry, center of pressure, and coefficient of variability.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS) having mild disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the associations between individual items of the MSWS-12 and mobility in people with multiple sclerosis (MS), and whether these associations vary by disability level.
results_summary: The study found that specific items of the MSWS-12, particularly those related to the use of walking support indoors and outdoors, were strongly correlated with mobility test results. These associations were more pronounced in mildly disabled individuals compared to moderately-severely disabled individuals.
population_specificity: 242 people with multiple sclerosis (108 mildly disabled and 134 moderately-severely disabled).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy (mortality, hospitalization, cardiac function, and quality of life) and safety of testosterone in heart failure patients, including its impact on walking distance.
results_summary: Testosterone use was associated with improved walking distance in 5 studies, but no difference in mortality or HF hospitalization was observed. Quality of life improvements were inconsistent, and no increase in side effects was reported.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of messaging interventions (psychological or physical benefits) combined with goal setting and self-monitoring to promote walking activity among university students.
results_summary: Participants in the experimental conditions showed improvements in psychological variables and walking behavior, with physical health messages combined with self-monitoring being the most effective.
population_specificity: 230 university students from the University of Naples Federico II (156 completed all measures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare oscillometry and cw-Doppler for determining PAD severity via ABI and assess the role of tissue microperfusion in pedal PAD.
results_summary: The study found that oscillometric ABI measures the strongest signal but misses lower values compared to cw-Doppler, and neither method accounts for pedal perfusion. TOPP from photoplethysmography was used to assess microperfusion in 323 patients.
population_specificity: 323 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), evaluated retrospectively in 3 independent groups.

study_goal: To determine if daily mobile-phone delivered training instructions improve physical activity and mobility in patients soon after stroke or transient ischemic attack.
results_summary: The intervention group showed improved walking performance (30-meter median difference in the six-minute walking test) and lower body strength compared to the control group after three months.
population_specificity: 79 patients (mean age 63.9 years, 29 women) soon after stroke or transient ischemic attack.
effective_dosage: Daily mobile phone instructional text messages for outdoor walking and functional leg exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional mobility outcomes among three new physical therapy protocols versus a standard post-TKA rehabilitation protocol.
results_summary: The study found no statistically or clinically significant differences in mobility outcomes across the four intervention groups, with similar improvements in Activity Measure for Post-acute Care scores and 6-minute walk test distances.
population_specificity: Patients aged 40+ who underwent elective unilateral TKA and began outpatient physical therapy within 24 days post-surgery.
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated (measured at baseline, monthly, and on discharge)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of visual gait biofeedback combined with impairment-based rehabilitation on gait biomechanics and patient-reported outcomes in individuals with chronic ankle instability.
results_summary: The visual gait biofeedback group significantly reduced ankle inversion angles and showed greater improvements in patient-reported outcomes compared to the no-biofeedback group, though no significant differences were found in kinetics or electromyography measures.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI)
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of impairment-based rehabilitation (GBF group received additional visual biofeedback during treadmill walking)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), calf muscle pathology, and walking performance, as well as potential interventions to improve walking in PAD patients.
results_summary: The study found that adverse calf muscle characteristics (e.g., reduced density, fat infiltration, fibrosis) are associated with mobility loss in PAD patients. Preliminary evidence suggests that interventions like revascularization and cocoa flavanols may improve muscle health and walking performance.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; cocoa flavanols dosage not detailed.
study_duration: Not specified for walking; pilot trial duration not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 12-week aerobic walking intervention on cognitive function among adult cancer survivors, relative to yoga and stretch and tone exercises.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for walking, but the study aims to assess its efficacy in improving cognitive function and cardiovascular fitness in cancer survivors.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the magnitude and patterns of cognitive-motor dual-task interference during walking in stroke survivors at hospital discharge and explore associated characteristics.
results_summary: The study found significant dual-task declines in gait speed, stride length, and cadence, but no effects on stride duration variability or cognitive task performance. Three patterns of interference were identified: mutual interference, gait interference, and cognitive-priority trade-off, linked to different clinical characteristics.
population_specificity: Forty-seven adults with stroke being discharged to home (mean age 59.5 years, median 14 days post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking training on different surfaces versus overground walking training on functional ability and fall incidence in ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Participants in the experimental group (walking on varied surfaces) showed significant functional improvement at 2 and 4 weeks and had fewer falls (18%) compared to the control group (46%) over 6 months.
population_specificity: Independent ambulatory individuals with spinal cord injury (N=54), walking with or without a device.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify neuroanatomical models explaining selective muscle weakness in SMA and assess their relationship to ambulatory function.
results_summary: The study found that muscles innervated by lower lumbar and sacral segments (hip extensors, abductors, knee flexors, and ankle dorsiflexors) strongly correlated with and predicted better walking performance, explaining 67% of variability in 6MWT results.
population_specificity: 23 ambulatory individuals with SMA III (ages 10-56, 78.2% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the test-retest reliability of daily physical activity (DPA) gait performance parameters and quantitative gait measures between two separate days of assessment among older adults.
results_summary: Most gait performance parameters showed good to excellent repeatability (ICC ≥ 0.70), while quantitative measures like step count and walking duration had poor repeatability (ICC < 0.30). Pre-frail/frail individuals exhibited higher repeatability in gait performance parameters compared to non-frail individuals.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥ 65 years, including non-frail and pre-frail/frail individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a teach-back training method (TBTM) for respiratory exercises, including walking (6MWT), in improving clinical outcomes for COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in FEV1/FVC ratio and Borg scale of dyspnea (BSD) after TBTM, with long-term benefits in 6-minute walking test (6MWT) distance observed at 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Eighty exacerbated COPD patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (respiratory exercises included diaphragmatic breathing, pursed-lip breathing, and effective coughing).

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of high-intensity cycling in improving walking capacity in individuals with chronic stroke and identify predictors of improvement.
results_summary: Significant improvements in walking capacity were observed in both forced and voluntary aerobic exercise groups, but not in the control group. Baseline walking capacity, cycling cadence, and power output were significant predictors of improvement.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke (N=43).
effective_dosage: 3 times per week for 8 weeks at 60-80% of heart rate reserve with moderate to high cadence and resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the control of linear accelerations at the head and trunk during gait in individuals with unilateral vestibular loss compared to vestibular healthy participants under different sensory conditions.
results_summary: Participants with vestibular loss showed significantly greater impairment in controlling head and trunk accelerations when visual sensory information was removed (eyes closed) compared to healthy participants, as measured by clinically available inertial measurement units. The effects were statistically significant across all three directional planes (cranial-caudal, medial-lateral, anterior-posterior) at both the head and trunk.
population_specificity: Individuals (n=13) 6 weeks after vestibular schwannoma resection surgery (mean age 47.6±13.7y; 69% women) and vestibular healthy participants (n=16; mean age 29.7±5.9y; 56% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe how to establish a whole blood-based blood preparedness program, including an emergency walking blood bank, in small rural hospitals with limited resources.
results_summary: The study found that implementing a whole blood program is feasible in small rural hospitals and recommended protocols for early balanced transfusion in life-threatening bleeding situations. The abstract highlights the logistical advantages of whole blood and the importance of training and audits.
population_specificity: Small rural hospitals with limited resources.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of gene-by-neighborhood social environment interactions on waist circumference as a marker of metabolic risk in African-American adults, focusing on walking-related environmental interventions.
results_summary: The study found significant gene-by-environment interactions affecting waist circumference, with higher genetic risk and lower social-environmental supports associated with higher waist circumference. One interaction was inconsistent with the dual-risk hypothesis.
population_specificity: Underserved African-American adults from higher-crime neighborhoods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study how real-life environmental dimensions affect muscle activity and gait velocity in stroke survivors during walking.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in muscle activity of the hemiparetic lower limb and lower gait velocity in real-life environments compared to even surfaces. Stroke survivors reported the highest difficulty during stair and obstacle clearance.
population_specificity: 16 ambulatory stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait training using the Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) exoskeletal robot improved the ability to perform activities of daily living (ADL) in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that stroke patients undergoing HAL rehabilitation showed significantly higher ADL ability (measured by FIM scores) and were more likely to achieve practical walking ability compared to those receiving conventional rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Acute stroke patients admitted to the facility between April 2016 and June 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a walking program could prevent insomnia in the third trimester of pregnancy, improve sleep quality, and enhance overall quality of life.
results_summary: The study proposes that promoting walking in the second half of pregnancy, particularly with a goal of 10,000-11,000 steps/day, may prevent insomnia, improve sleep quality, and enhance quality of life, though final results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Healthy sedentary pregnant women (n=265) from a university hospital in Granada, Spain.
effective_dosage: Intervention group I1: 11,000 steps/day; Intervention group I2: pedometer use without a step goal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and applicability of smart insole technology for gait analysis in stroke patients with hemiplegia, comparing it to traditional assessment methods.
results_summary: The study found that smart insole gait parameters closely matched manually collected data, with 14 of 18 parameters effectively distinguishing patients from healthy controls. The data revealed significant differences in stance and swing durations between patients and controls, and identified correlations between gait parameters and stroke severity scales, particularly the Fugl-Meyer Assessment.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with hemiplegia and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and efficacy of a 6-month SystemCHANGE™ + Activity Tracker intervention to increase daily steps and improve health outcomes in older kidney transplant recipients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant increase in daily steps at 3 months (mean difference of 608 steps) and maintained this increase at 6 months. The study protocol was feasible with high adherence, suggesting the intervention is effective for increasing physical activity in this population.
population_specificity: Older kidney transplant recipients (mean age 65 years, 66% male, 57% white).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention focused on achieving daily step goals using an activity tracker).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether spironolactone could improve exercise capacity (measured by peak oxygen consumption), E/e' ratio, and quality of life in patients with permanent atrial fibrillation and preserved ejection fraction.
results_summary: Spironolactone did not improve peak oxygen consumption compared to placebo at 2 years, with no significant difference observed. Secondary outcomes, including 6-minute walk distance, E/e' ratio, and quality of life, were also not significantly improved.
population_specificity: Stable patients with permanent atrial fibrillation and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of Nordic walking as a physiotherapy intervention for improving motor symptoms, balance, and gait in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Nordic walking was found to improve motor symptoms, balance, and gait in people with Parkinson's disease, based on the meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of standard outpatient pulmonary rehabilitation versus home-based tele-rehabilitation on walking distance (6MWD) in severe COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in six-minute walking distance (6MWD) between the control and intervention groups immediately after the program or at the 12-month follow-up. Hospitalization and mortality outcomes were also analyzed, but no significant differences were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with severe COPD from 8 hospitals in the Capital Region of Denmark.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was conducted at 12 months.

study_goal: To investigate the short-term effect of self-selected training intensity (SSTI) on ambulatory blood pressure and six-minute walking test performance in hypertensive older women.
results_summary: The SSTI group showed improved six-minute walking test performance but no significant changes in ambulatory blood pressure compared to the control group. Participants exercised at moderate intensity (52±10% of HR reserve) with positive affective valence (3.4±1.1).
population_specificity: Medicated hypertensive older women (64.4±3.6 years).
effective_dosage: Three times per week, 30-50 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of intrathecally delivered rituximab on progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS) over a 3-year follow-up period.
results_summary: The study found that IT rituximab was well tolerated but associated with mild to moderate vertigo, nausea, and two cases of bacterial meningitis. Walking speed deteriorated significantly, indicating the treatment did not halt disease progression.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS).

study_goal: To develop a prognostic model predicting short-term fall risk (7-30 days) in older adults with dementia using gait stability and fall history.
results_summary: The model showed fair to good predictive ability, with gait stability and recent fall history as significant predictors of imminent falls. The area under the receiver operating curve was 0.80 at 7 days and 0.67 at 30 days.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia at high risk of falls from a specialized inpatient unit.
study_duration: 2-week baseline gait recording, falls tracked throughout hospital stay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop quantitative indices to measure gait deterioration effects in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients and healthy subjects during prolonged walking.
results_summary: The study found that walking-related fatigue in MS patients led to increased gait variability and asymmetry, with hip asymmetry strongly correlating with clinical disability. The proposed indices showed good to excellent reliability and repeatability.
population_specificity: Nine patients with multiple sclerosis and twenty-six healthy subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare spinal posture and pelvic position under static and dynamic (walking) conditions using rasterstereography to improve understanding and treatment of spinal pathologies.
results_summary: The study found that spinal posture differs between females and males during standing and walking, with significant changes in trunk inclination, lordotic angle, and other parameters under dynamic conditions. Rasterstereography proved valuable for dynamic evaluation of spinal posture and pelvic position.
population_specificity: 121 healthy volunteers (56 females, 65 males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of short-term, low-dose oral prednisolone for improving walking ability and reducing pain in patients with refractory lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study found that a one-week treatment with 10 mg oral prednisolone did not significantly improve pain severity or disability scores compared to placebo, though walking distance increased in both groups without statistical significance between them.
population_specificity: Patients with refractory lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) from outpatient clinics.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of an advanced practice nurse-guided home-based rehabilitation exercise program (HREPro) for improving lower limb spasticity, motor function, walking ability, and activities of daily living in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The HREPro significantly improved lower limb spasticity, motor function, walking ability, and activities of daily living compared to conventional rehabilitation, with notable differences at 6 and 12 months post-discharge.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb spasticity post-stroke (n=121).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a self-efficacy intervention versus an attention-control intervention on physical activity, clinical outcomes, and mediators in older adults with knee osteoarthritis and hypertension.
results_summary: The intervention improved self-reported lower-extremity exercise, fitness walking, function, pain, self-efficacy, and outcome expectancy but did not significantly improve objectively measured physical activity (accelerometer) or blood pressure. Mean fitness walking minutes fell short of the 150 min/week goal.
population_specificity: Older adults with knee osteoarthritis and hypertension (n=182).
effective_dosage: Six weekly individual physical therapy sessions for lower-extremity exercise and fitness walking, plus nine biweekly nurse telephone counseling sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify modifiable factors related to physical play/leisure (PPP) in children with motor impairments, including walking, to inform therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that family PPP and movement-related impairments explained 18% of the variation in PPP, with family PPP being the most significant factor. Children preferred active play but reported adult regulation of their activities.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-8 years with motor impairments, mobilizing independently with or without equipment, and their parents in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a smartphone-based model for estimating heart rate in cardiac patients to guide outdoor walking sessions and prevent overstrain.
results_summary: The study achieved an average Median Absolute Deviation (MAD) of 4.26 BPM between measured heart rate and model estimation, suggesting reasonable accuracy for guiding walking sessions. Three levels of improvement were tested via cross-validation, indicating iterative refinement of the model.
population_specificity: Cardiac patients taking β-blockers (9 participants).
study_duration: Three outdoor sessions per patient (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reducing sedentary time alone improves vascular endothelial function in older adults, and whether achieving moderate-intensity physical activity (PA) in bouts enhances this effect.
results_summary: Reducing sedentary time by up to 100 minutes per day over 12 weeks did not significantly improve vascular endothelial function, but those who achieved ≥20 minutes/day of moderate-intensity PA in bouts ≥10 minutes showed significant improvement in FMD%.
population_specificity: 96 adults aged ≥50 years who were sedentary.
effective_dosage: ≥20 minutes/day of moderate-intensity PA in bouts ≥10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-month aerobic walking exercise program on gait parameters (step cadence, step length, ground contact time) in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in gait parameters, including increased ground contact time, decreased step cadence, and increased step length at specific treadmill load steps after 12 months. No changes were observed in the internal control group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients with relapsing-remitting MS and an EDSS score ≤3.5.
effective_dosage: Individualized twelve-month aerobic endurance exercise program (details not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a group-mediated cognitive behavioral intervention promoting unsupervised walking exercise could prevent mobility loss and improve functional performance in people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced mobility loss (6.3% vs. 26.5% at 6 months, 5.2% vs. 18.5% at 12 months) and improved fast-paced walking velocity and Short Physical Performance Battery scores compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (90% of exercise was conducted at or near home).
study_duration: 12 months (6 months of active intervention, 6 months of telephone follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week enhanced physiotherapy and structured exercise program (PEPSE) combined with an essential amino acid supplement (GEAA) improves physical and psychological recovery in intensive care patients.
results_summary: Patients receiving both PEPSE and GEAA showed significant improvements in the 6-minute walking test and reductions in anxiety and depression rates compared to other groups. The combination of PEPSE and GEAA yielded the most substantial gains in physical recovery and psychological well-being.
population_specificity: Intensive care patients aged 45 years or older with a combined ICU/pre-ICU stay of 5 days or more.
effective_dosage: GEAA drink twice daily for 3 months.
study_duration: 6 weeks for PEPSE, 3 months for GEAA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) transplantation on knee osteoarthritis (OA) symptoms, including walking ability.
results_summary: MSC transplantation improved knee OA symptoms (e.g., walking time, pain) at 6 months, with gradual deterioration over 5 years, though still better than baseline. The untreated knee worsened over time.
population_specificity: Four patients (ages 54-65) with moderate to severe knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 8-9 × 10^6 MSC injected once into the worse knee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Shenfu injection loading in treating acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure due to coronary heart disease, focusing on symptoms, exercise tolerance, and short-term prognosis.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a clinical trial to evaluate Shenfu injection's effects on heart failure symptoms, exercise tolerance (including 6-minute walking distance), and short-term prognosis, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Inpatients with acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure due to coronary heart disease (yang and qi deficiency syndrome).
effective_dosage: Treatment group: 100 ml 5% glucose injection + 50 ml Shenfu injection; control group: 150 ml 5% glucose injection.
study_duration: 7 ± 1 days of intervention, with follow-up for 28 ± 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fall prevention interventions, including mobility improvements, in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Nine out of ten interventions reported a reduction in falls and/or proportion of fallers, with most also observing improved balance. However, methodological limitations prevent definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) with a wide range of disability levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of clinical outcome instruments and characterize the recovery course after copperhead snakebite, including functional impairments like walking speed.
results_summary: The study found that abnormalities in walking speed and other functional impairments persisted for 7-14 days in most subjects, with some residual effects lasting up to 28 days. Walking speed measurements were less responsive than self-reported outcome measures.
population_specificity: Patients envenomated by copperhead snakes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a behavioral activities intervention (BE-ACTIV) versus a Walking and Talking intervention on mood and quality of life in nursing home residents with mild to moderate dementia.
results_summary: The study found qualitative improvements in mood for residents receiving BE-ACTIV, but no statistically significant treatment effect was observed. The Walking and Talking intervention was not directly compared in terms of efficacy, but the study highlighted the feasibility and acceptability of individualized activities for dementia patients.
population_specificity: Australian nursing home residents with mild to moderate dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking exercises (aerobic exercise) improved biochemical and physical indices in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Walking exercises significantly improved glycosylated hemoglobin, postprandial glucose, fasting serum insulin, triglyceride, and total cholesterol levels compared to the control group, with sustained benefits observed at follow-up, though body mass index did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mesoglycan on endothelial function, atherosclerotic damage, and clinical condition (walking distance) in peripheral arterial disease (PAD) patients.
results_summary: Mesoglycan treatment significantly improved flow-mediated dilation (FMD), reduced femoral intima-medial thickness (IMT), and increased walking distance (WD) by 38.9%. These benefits persisted during treatment-free intervals.
population_specificity: 540 patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
study_duration: 2 months of treatment followed by 2 months without treatment, repeated over 6 months.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in treating chronic systolic heart failure, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that umbilical cord MSCs improved cardiac function and reduced mortality in heart failure patients, but it did not assess Walking.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with chronic systolic heart failure.
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (related to MSCs, not Walking).
study_duration: 1 and 6 months post-treatment (related to MSCs, not Walking).
interactions: None mentioned (related to MSCs, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of supervised exercise, medical therapy, and revascularization in improving walking distance and quality of life in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Exercise training improved maximal walking distance and initial claudication distance compared to usual care, while all modalities improved quality of life without significant differences between treatments. Mortality and safety data were insufficient to assess treatment-related complications.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a home-based adapted physical activity (APA) program, including walking, on aerobic capacity, strength, and fatigue in women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer compared to usual care.
results_summary: The APA program increased VO2peak in the intervention group but showed no significant differences between groups for cardiopulmonary exercise tests, 6MWT, quadriceps strength, or quality of life. Heavy evaluation tests may have contributed to non-adherence and lack of statistically significant results.
population_specificity: Women treated with adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy for breast cancer (n=44).
effective_dosage: Combined endurance and resistance training program, frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review cardiovascular abnormalities and autonomic dysfunction following spinal cord injury, including their mechanisms and long-term consequences.
results_summary: The abstract describes the prevalence and severity of cardiovascular issues post-SCI, such as orthostatic hypotension and autonomic dysreflexia, but does not address walking or its effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with high-level spinal cord injuries.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of home-based versus hospital-based rehabilitation programs in improving knee joint mobility, muscle strength, and functional recovery after total knee replacement.
results_summary: Both home-based and hospital-based rehabilitation programs significantly improved pain levels, range of motion, muscle strength, disability indices, balance, and walking ability, with no significant differences between the two approaches.
population_specificity: Seventy-eight patients with prosthetic knees post-total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of VR-based interventions on balance and mobility disorders post stroke.
results_summary: VR-based interventions showed significant improvements in dynamic balance, walking speed, and the ability to handle environmental challenges, potentially aiding independent community ambulation. The study suggested that motor learning principles like task-related training contributed to positive outcomes, but further investigation into factors like repetition and feedback is needed.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with balance and mobility disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in gait quality after total hip arthroplasty using the Gait Deviation Index (GDI) and identify predictive factors for outcome.
results_summary: The study found no difference in gait improvement between resurfacing and conventional hip arthroplasty, but overall gait quality improved post-surgery, particularly in participants with the most pathological preoperative gait patterns. The preoperative GDI score was a strong predictor of postoperative improvement.
population_specificity: 38 participants with severe unilateral primary hip osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To examine the effect of kinesiology tape (KT) on gastrocnemius muscle activity and ankle range of motion during walking in healthy subjects.
results_summary: KT significantly shortened the duration and onset of lateral gastrocnemius (LG) muscle activity during gait but did not significantly affect LG SEMG amplitude or other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty-six healthy physiotherapy students.

study_goal: To determine the effect of kinesiotaping versus sham kinesiotaping on repositioning pronated feet after short-duration running.
results_summary: Kinesiotaping reduced foot pronation more than sham taping, but sham taping had a greater effect on pressure variables during walking. The study found statistically significant differences between the two treatments.
population_specificity: 73 amateur runners with pronated foot types (FPI score ≥6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait training with a gait-assistance robot (GAR) improves gait disturbances in subacute non-ambulatory hemiplegic stroke patients more than conventional overground gait training.
results_summary: The GAR-assisted gait training group showed significantly greater improvements in Functional Ambulation Classification (FAC) and peak torque on the unaffected side compared to the conventional training group, with a trend toward faster gait speed.
population_specificity: Subacute non-ambulatory hemiplegic stroke patients (n=26).
effective_dosage: 60 min of standard physical therapy and 20 min of GAR-assisted or conventional gait training, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of an internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy program (MSInvigor8) with and without email support in reducing fatigue severity and impact, as well as improving mood, in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: MSInvigor8 with email support (MSInvigor8-Plus) significantly reduced fatigue severity and impact compared to the program without email support (MSInvigor8-Only), with large effect sizes. No significant differences were found between groups for anxiety and depression.
population_specificity: 39 people with multiple sclerosis (aged 31-63 years) experiencing fatigue and able to walk with or without aids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether revascularization improves walking ability (measured by highest-MDCW and average-WSCW) in patients with arterial claudication.
results_summary: Revascularized patients showed significant improvements in highest-MDCW (+442m vs. +13m) and average-WSCW (+0.3 km/h vs. -0.2 km/h) compared to reference patients. However, no significant difference was found in average-DSCW changes between groups.
population_specificity: 251 peripheral artery disease patients with self-reported limiting claudication, narrowed to 44 revascularized and 39 reference patients for analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pulsed radio frequency treatment for managing pain and improving walking comfort in patients with Morton's neuroma.
results_summary: The study found that pulsed radio frequency reduced pain levels in 18 of 20 patients, achieved successful pain control in 12, and enabled 16 patients to walk and wear shoes without pain. Overall, 12 patients rated their satisfaction as excellent or good.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with symptomatic Morton's neuroma unresponsive to conservative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationships between movement frequencies in walking, running, and cycling, and the effects of strength training on locomotion behavior.
results_summary: The study found that stride frequencies in walking and running were positively correlated, but no significant correlations existed between these and pedaling frequency. Strength training did not affect stride characteristics in walking or running, contrasting with previous findings in cycling.
population_specificity: 27 participants (with subsets of 9 each for different training interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ambulation and rehabilitation during ECMO support as a bridge to lung transplantation in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that ambulatory ECMO programs improved rehabilitation, minimized sedation, and enhanced posttransplant outcomes, though implementation strategies remain unclear.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients awaiting lung transplantation on ECMO support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of custom foot orthoses (CFO), prefabricated foot orthoses (PFO), and sham insoles for treating plantar fasciitis, focusing on pain, function, and physical activity.
results_summary: The CFO group showed significant improvements in foot function, spontaneous physical activity, and balance compared to PFO and sham groups, with a 125% increase in walking episodes. All groups reported reduced morning and evening pain, but CFOs led to less reliance on stretching and ice after 3 months.
population_specificity: 77 patients with plantar fasciitis for less than 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and safety of intensive walking exercise in peripheral arterial disease (PAD) patients with and without intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: Intensive walking exercise significantly improved maximal walking distance, pain-free walking distance, and 6-minute walking distance in PAD patients compared to usual care, with no significant difference in adverse events between groups. The presence of diabetes attenuated improvements in walking performance.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD), including those with and without intermittent claudication (IC).
study_duration: Varied across included trials (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of shock wave therapy alone versus shock wave therapy combined with plantar fascia-specific stretching in treating chronic plantar heel pain.
results_summary: The study found that combining shock wave therapy with plantar fascia-specific stretching resulted in significantly greater improvements in pain and function at two and four months compared to shock wave therapy alone, though differences were not sustained at 24 months. Patient satisfaction was also higher in the combined treatment group.
population_specificity: 152 patients with chronic unilateral plantar fasciopathy lasting at least 12 months who had failed at least three other treatments.
effective_dosage: Weekly low-energy radial shock-wave therapy for three weeks (Group 1) or the same shock wave therapy plus an eight-week plantar fascia-specific stretching program (Group 2).
study_duration: Follow-up evaluations at 2, 4, and 24 months post-baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight sex-based disparities in lower extremity peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and the importance of timely diagnosis and intervention to improve walking capacity and cardiovascular outcomes in women.
results_summary: The study found that women with PAD experience greater cardiovascular risks, reduced exercise capacity, and poorer quality of life compared to men, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and risk factor modification to improve walking capacity and overall outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with lower extremity peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: To evaluate and compare the effects of intensive exercise therapy modalities (Resistance Training, Endurance Training, and Other Intensive Training Modalities) on Parkinson's Disease.
results_summary: Intensive exercise therapy (including walking) is feasible and safe in Parkinson's Disease, with strong evidence that Resistance Training improves muscle strength and moderate evidence that Endurance Training improves cardio-respiratory fitness. Walking performance may benefit, but findings are inconsistent.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's Disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether computerized spatial navigation training could mitigate declines in walking performance (normal and dual-task) caused by prolonged bed rest in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group showed smaller declines in walking performance post-bed rest compared to the control group, suggesting that spatial navigation training can help moderate the negative effects of inactivity on motor function.
population_specificity: Healthy older adult men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of lipoprotein apheresis (LA) on walking distance and other clinical parameters in patients with severe peripheral artery disease (PAD) and hyperlipoproteinemia(a).
results_summary: LA significantly improved walking distance (from 87 ± 60 m to 313 ± 145 m), pain levels, ankle-brachial-index, and transcutaneous oxygen pressure, while strongly reducing the frequency of revascularization procedures.
population_specificity: Patients with severe PAD and isolated hyperlipoproteinemia(a) who recently underwent revascularization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the baseline characteristics, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), and factors associated with HRQoL in patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD)-associated emphysema, including the association between walking (6-min walking distance) and HRQoL.
results_summary: The study found a significant negative correlation between the 6-min walking distance and the SGRQ score (r = -0.53, p < 0.0001), indicating better HRQoL with greater walking capacity. Walking distance was also included in a multivariate model explaining 57% of the variation in HRQoL scores.
population_specificity: 273 French patients with AATD-associated emphysema, obstructive-pattern (FEV1/FVC < 0.7), and FEV1 ≤ 80% predicted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of sensorimotor orthoses on in-shoe and lower limb biomechanics in adults with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease during walking.
results_summary: Sensorimotor orthoses improved midfoot and ankle kinematics, increased medial ground reaction forces, and were rated higher for comfort, cushioning, and stability compared to shoes alone. The orthoses also produced small but significant changes at the knee and hip, indicating increased internal rotation.
population_specificity: Adults (8 males, 2 females, aged 31-68 years) with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
