study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a therapist-made ankle-foot orthosis (SWIFT Cast) improved walking recovery compared to conventional physical therapy in individuals post-stroke.
results_summary: The SWIFT Cast did not significantly enhance walking speed compared to conventional therapy, though the control group used other AFOs more frequently. The SWIFT Cast remains a viable low-cost, customizable option for rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Individuals 3 to 42 days post-stroke (n = 105).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved use during physical therapy sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of two interventions (attendance incentives and tailored support) in encouraging the ongoing use of a new community-based physical activity facility, including its impact on physical activity participation and wellbeing.
results_summary: The study will assess facility usage, physical activity participation, and wellbeing outcomes, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract. The focus is on comparing the effectiveness of attendance incentives versus incentives combined with tailored support.
population_specificity: Physically inactive adults aged 18-70 years (n=1,300).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of single-limb versus two-limb high-repetitive resistance training on functional exercise capacity and muscle function in patients with COPD and to investigate underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results in the abstract, but it focused on measuring changes in 6-minute walking distance, muscle strength, endurance, and other physiological markers after 8 weeks of training. The abstract indicates the study will provide insights into the comparative efficacy and mechanisms of these training modalities.
population_specificity: Patients with stable severe to very severe COPD aged over 40 and healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Three times/week for 8 weeks (using elastic bands).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effects of intra-myocardial autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cell (MSC) treatment on patients with severe ischaemic heart failure, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that MSC treatment improved myocardial function (e.g., reduced LVESV, increased LVEF) but did not assess Walking. No differences were observed in NYHA class, 6-min walking test, or Kansas City cardiomyopathy questionnaire.
population_specificity: Patients aged 30-80 with severe ischaemic heart failure (NYHA classes II-III, LVEF <45%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding ivabradine to low-dose bisoprolol during cardiac rehabilitation improves functional capacity, diastolic function, and systolic function recovery in post-CABG patients.
results_summary: Adding ivabradine to low-dose bisoprolol improved functional capacity (measured by 6MWT distance), restored diastolic function, and enhanced systolic function recovery compared to standard therapy alone.
population_specificity: Patients admitted for cardiac rehabilitation after recent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).
effective_dosage: Ivabradine 5 mg twice daily + bisoprolol 1.25 mg once daily (group I-BB) vs. bisoprolol 2.5-3.75 mg once daily (group BB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions, including supervised exercise training and pedometer-based walking, in improving exercise capacity and quality of life for lung transplant recipients before and after transplantation.
results_summary: Outpatient rehabilitation programs, including supervised exercise training, were effective in improving limb muscle dysfunction, exercise capacity, and quality of life for lung transplant recipients. Remotely monitored home-based exercise or pedometer-based walking interventions showed promise as alternatives to supervised programs in the long-term posttransplant phase.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage lung disease, both pre- and post-lung transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sensitive gait parameters that could objectively measure physical improvements in patients with low back disorders after surgical intervention.
results_summary: The study found that for scoliosis patients, spinal fusion improved hip and shoulder motion, energy expenditure, and upper-body muscle symmetry during gait. For spinal stenosis patients, decompression surgery increased gait speed, stride length, cadence, symmetry, smoothness, endurance, and reduced gait variability.
population_specificity: Individuals with low back disorders requiring surgery (specifically scoliosis/spinal fusion or stenosis/decompression).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of prolonged-release fampridine on walking disability, balance, and safety in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: PR-fampridine therapy resulted in significant improvements in walking disability (MSWS-12), dynamic balance (TUG speed), and static balance (BBS) compared to placebo over 24 weeks, with a higher proportion of patients achieving clinically meaningful improvements. The treatment was well tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive or relapsing-remitting MS and an Expanded Disability Status Scale score of 4.0-7.0.
effective_dosage: Twice daily (specific dosage not mentioned in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether specific combined cup and stem anteversion rules in total hip arthroplasty (THA) influenced postoperative gait patterns, gait improvement, and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that standard combined anteversion rules and Lewinnek's "safe zone" did not significantly affect range of motion, walking speed, hip flexion symmetry, or clinical outcomes (HHS, HOOS, EQ-5D) within one year after THA. Gait parameter improvements were comparable across all anteversion definitions.
population_specificity: 60 patients who underwent cementless THA via an anterolateral MIS approach.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of task-oriented treadmill-walking training (TOTWT) on walking ability in stroke patients compared to conventional treadmill-walking training (CTWT).
results_summary: Both TOTWT and CTWT groups showed significant improvements in gait parameters and walking tests after the intervention, with the TOTWT group demonstrating greater improvement than the CTWT group. TOTWT was found to enhance gait and rehabilitation in stroke-affected limbs and improve general gait characteristics.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between neighborhood environmental perceptions, poverty, and blood pressure in at-risk African-American adults, as part of a community-based intervention to increase walking.
results_summary: Higher neighborhood satisfaction was associated with lower systolic and diastolic blood pressure when perceived crime was high, while neighborhood poverty was linked to higher blood pressure. The study found no significant individual-level direct associations but noted cross-product interactions between perceived crime and satisfaction affecting blood pressure.
population_specificity: African-American adults in low-income, high-crime neighborhoods (N = 409).
study_duration: Baseline data collected in 2008 (intervention duration not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how well the Neuromuscular Recovery Scale (NRS) items fit the Rasch measurement model, with Walking identified as the most challenging item.
results_summary: The NRS met many Rasch model criteria for construct validity, with Walking being the most difficult item. The scale showed no ceiling or floor effects and effectively stratified patients by ability level.
population_specificity: Outpatients (N=188) with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level sporting compression tights could reduce fluid buildup in limbs during exercise (treadmill walking) for individuals with early-stage lymphedema and healthy controls.
results_summary: Sporting compression tights significantly reduced fluid buildup post-exercise in lymphedema-affected limbs (measured via BIS) and decreased limb volume in the entire cohort (measured via Perometry). The effects were statistically significant, supporting their use for lymphedema management during exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy controls (n=10) and Stage 1 lymphedema patients (n=9).
effective_dosage: Standardized treadmill walking at increasing rates within individual activity limits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a behavioral intervention program, including walking (via walking poles and pedometers), on gestational weight gain and postpartum weight retention in obese pregnant women.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly lower gestational weight gain (8.6 kg vs. 12.5 kg) and lower postpartum weight retention (-0.2 kg vs. +2.0 kg) compared to controls, with more women achieving weight gain below 7 kg (36% vs. 16%).
population_specificity: Obese pregnant women (BMI ≥30) in Gothenburg, Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking poles and pedometers provided, but exact walking dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (intervention administered during antenatal care).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of external oblique abdominal muscle transfer versus no muscle transfer in improving hip stability and functional outcomes in pediatric patients with lower lumbar myelomeningocele.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in radiographic hip stability between the two groups, though abductor strength improved with muscle transfer. However, this improvement did not translate to better mobility or reduced need for orthoses.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (mean age 6 years) with L3 to L5 level myelomeningocele and hip instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical research on angiogenic and stem cell therapies as alternative treatments for peripheral arterial disease, particularly in patients unresponsive to conventional therapies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the limitations of current treatments for peripheral arterial disease, such as surgical bypass and catheter-based interventions, and explores the potential of angiogenic cytokines and stem/progenitor cell therapies as alternative treatments. It summarizes preclinical and clinical research, identifies knowledge gaps, and suggests future directions to address unmet medical needs.
population_specificity: Patients with severe peripheral arterial disease unresponsive to medical treatment and procedural revascularization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and sufficiency of a "walking blood bank" for providing blood supply in a military treatment facility in Afghanistan.
results_summary: The study found that the "walking blood bank" provided a quick, safe, and sufficient blood supply, with 93 blood bags collected, including rare blood types. The risk of blood shortage was low due to the large number of potential donors.
population_specificity: Military personnel deployed in Afghanistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying exercise impairment in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) during walking.
results_summary: The study found that PAD impairs oxygen and metabolic substrate supply during walking, but hemodynamic factors alone do not fully explain the exercise impairment. Additional mechanisms like endothelial dysfunction, oxidant stress, inflammation, and muscle metabolic abnormalities contribute to the condition.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), including those with classic or atypical claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-week combined exercise program (resistance, endurance, and balance training) on gait performance, including gait variability, in older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in gait endurance (6-min walk test) and gait parameters (velocity, stride time, stride length) after 8 and 12 weeks of combined exercise, demonstrating positive effects on gait performance in both habitual and fast walking conditions.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (n=29, experimental group=17, control group=12).
effective_dosage: 1 hour per day, 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of nurse-delivered physical activity interventions, particularly walking, in primary care settings.
results_summary: Nearly 80% of the studies reported significant increases in walking and other physical activities, with tailored techniques like stage-specific strategies and individualized goal-setting being most effective.
population_specificity: 7,350 participants across 19 national and international studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing physical activity to public health guideline levels (≥150 min/week of moderate- to vigorous-intensity activity) improves sleep quality in inactive adults with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that the physical activity intervention significantly reduced insomnia symptom severity, depression, and anxiety scores, but had no significant effect on daytime fatigue. All improvements were independent of daily light exposure.
population_specificity: Inactive adults meeting research diagnostic criteria for insomnia (N=41; 30 females).
effective_dosage: ≥150 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dopamine modulates the effect of anxiety on gait in Parkinson's disease patients, using virtual reality to provoke anxiety and measure gait changes.
results_summary: The study found that walking in an anxiety-provoking (ELEVATED) condition increased skin conductance and self-reported anxiety, while slowing gait and increasing step variability. Dopaminergic treatment improved gait metrics (velocity, step length, step time, variability) only in highly anxious PD patients during the ELEVATED condition.
population_specificity: 17 Parkinson's disease patients (ON/OFF medication states) and 20 healthy age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a home-based moderate-intensity walking intervention could alleviate cognitive impairments and emotional distress in women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer.
results_summary: The study proposed that walking could improve cognitive function (memory, executive function, attention, visual spatial skills) and reduce emotional distress (fatigue, anxiety, depression, mood, self-esteem) in breast cancer patients, though specific results were not yet reported as the study was designed but not completed.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: Administered mid-way through chemotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe camptocormia, its characteristics, prevalence in Parkinson's disease, and potential treatment approaches.
results_summary: The study found that camptocormia is an axial postural deformity with thoracolumbar flexion, prevalent in 3-18% of Parkinson's disease cases, and may involve central and peripheral mechanisms. Non-pharmacological, pharmacological, and surgical treatments are available, but no consensus exists on optimal management.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease experiencing camptocormia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise therapy, including walking, reduces the knee adduction moment and improves pain, physical function, and muscle strength in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in knee adduction moment with exercise therapy, but significant improvements in pain, physical function, and muscle strength were observed. The clinical benefits of exercise therapy were not linked to changes in knee adduction moment.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best sensor types, locations, and outcome measures for assessing standing balance and walking stability in Parkinson's disease patients using wearable sensors.
results_summary: The review found that wearable sensors could detect differences in standing balance and walking stability between Parkinson's disease patients and controls, though methodological quality of studies was typically low to moderate. Further high-quality research is needed to confirm utility for early symptom identification and falls risk assessment.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of a pedometer-based intervention to increase physical activity and improve health-related outcomes in meat processing workers.
results_summary: The intervention group significantly increased their daily step count by 59% over baseline, maintaining this increase three months post-intervention, while the control group showed minimal change. No significant differences were found in physical or mental component scores between groups.
population_specificity: Meat processing workers in New Zealand (n = 58; mean age 41.0 years; range: 18-65).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer-based self-monitoring with goal setting and weekly e-mails).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of topical ketoprofen in Transfersome(®) gel (IDEA-033), oral ketoprofen, and drug-free Sequessome™ vesicles (FLEXISEQ(®) Sport; TDT 064) in reducing calf muscle soreness induced by walking down stairs.
results_summary: The study found that oral ketoprofen plus TDT 064 resulted in higher pain scores and longer recovery times compared to IDEA-033 plus placebo or TDT 064 plus placebo. TDT 064 alone showed potential for improving osteoarthritis-related pain and could be useful for joint pain during and post-exercise.
population_specificity: 168 healthy individuals with post-exercise calf muscle soreness (pain score ≥ 3 on a 10-point scale).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying locomotor recovery after spinal cord injury and the need for comprehensive assessment frameworks to evaluate therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study highlights the limitations of clinical scores in explaining recovery mechanisms and emphasizes the necessity of combining walking kinematics, spinal cord conductivity, and muscle activation assessments to capture subtle changes and differentiate between spontaneous recovery and therapy-induced improvements.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of endurance versus precision walking training on neural pathways and walking function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Both endurance and precision training improved walking function and increased excitability of inhibitory spinal networks, but only endurance training showed a positive correlation between motor-evoked potentials and clinical walking measures.
population_specificity: 16 participants with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
study_duration: 2 months per training type, with 2 months of rest between cross-over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of observing videos of walking people on physical activity, physical performance, cognition, and quality of life in older adults with dementia.
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of action observation (videos of walking) for physical activity and performance in dementia patients, with high feasibility and applicability in daily care, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia in residential care facilities.
effective_dosage: Videos shown on weekdays during the day for three months (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of post-discharge physiotherapy exercise, including walking skills, in improving physical function, pain, and performance outcomes in patients with recent primary total knee replacement.
results_summary: The study found that physiotherapy exercise, including walking skills, improved short-term physical function and pain in patients with total knee replacement, but no long-term benefits were identified. One study noted a long-term improvement in walking performance with a walking skills intervention, but overall, studies were underpowered.
population_specificity: Adults with recent primary total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and long-term impact of stochastic resonance whole-body vibration (SR-WBV) on static and dynamic balance and reaction time in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that SR-WBV was feasible with good recruitment and compliance rates, showing medium effect sizes in improving ETGUG total time but no significant changes in other balance or reaction time outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (20 participants).
effective_dosage: SR-WBV at 5 Hz with Noise 4 and 1 Hz with Noise 1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the ALS-MITOS system as a 6-month proxy for survival in ALS patients, comparing its predictive ability to the ALSFRS-R scale.
results_summary: The ALS-MITOS system predicted survival outcomes at 12 and 18 months with moderate sensitivity (71-82%) and specificity (63-68%), outperforming ALSFRS-R in identifying functional decline. The best predictive cut-off was a loss of at least one function (ALS-MITOS stage 1).
population_specificity: 200 ALS patients followed for up to 18 months.
study_duration: 6-month follow-up for prediction, up to 18 months for survival outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a pedometer-driven walking program in improving disability and clinical outcomes for adults with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week pedometer-driven walking program, combined with back care advice and education, was feasible and potentially effective for managing CLBP, with outcomes measured at 3, 6, and 12 months. Focus groups also explored participants' positive experiences with the walking program.
population_specificity: Adults with self-reported chronic low back pain (CLBP ≥ 12 weeks) in Saskatchewan, Canada.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer-driven walking program, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a virtual environment-based intervention could effectively teach pedestrian safety skills (street crossing and navigation) to adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Participants improved navigation performance but did not significantly reduce street-crossing errors in the virtual environment. However, caregivers reported significant real-life improvements in street-crossing skills.
population_specificity: Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective parameters (sensor placement, features, diurnal variation) for objectively measuring motor activity in depressed patients compared to healthy controls and monitoring treatment effects.
results_summary: Wrist-acceleration best distinguished depressed patients from healthy controls, showing reduced and decelerated motor activity. Differences in gestures and walking were also detected, with depressed patients walking less and slower.
population_specificity: Depressed patients (n=27 at baseline, n=18 post-treatment) and healthy controls (n=16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the clinical efficacy of ambrisentan in improving exercise tolerance and cardiac function in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that ambrisentan significantly improved 6-minute walking distance and reduced mean pulmonary arterial pressure, brain natriuretic peptide levels, and systolic pulmonary artery pressure in PH patients. However, limitations like small sample size and ethnic differences suggest the need for further validation.
population_specificity: 172 patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a workplace intervention promoting walking during the commute to increase moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) among working adults.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention, involving Walk-to-Work promoters and materials, aimed to increase daily MVPA and shift commuting habits away from private car use, with outcomes measured using accelerometers, GPS receivers, and travel diaries. Results were assessed at baseline, post-intervention, and one-year follow-up, though specific numerical outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Employees from workplaces in south-west England and south Wales.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved four contacts from promoters over 10 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dual-task functional power training (DT-FPT) could reduce the rate of falls in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study proposed a novel approach to falls prevention by focusing on optimizing muscle power and dual-task performance, with outcomes measured over 18 months, including falls rate, functional assessments, and cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 years residing in retirement villages, at increased risk of falling.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved supervised DT-FPT and a maintenance program).
study_duration: 18 months (6 months supervised DT-FPT, 6-month maintenance, 6-month follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and outcomes of a hybrid vascular approach for treating multilevel arterial occlusive disease in high-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found that a hybrid approach resulted in a 94.1% extremity survival rate, with minor complications such as wound infections (5%) and some cases requiring toe amputations (14%). One patient required a second procedure due to graft thrombosis, leading to a below-knee amputation.
population_specificity: 38 patients (29 male, 9 female) with multilevel arterial occlusive disease, mean age 68.1 years, presenting with claudication, resting pain, or disturbed tissue integrity.
study_duration: Follow-up duration not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a mail-based walking and nutrition intervention on muscle mass and anabolic hormones in older adults for sarcopenia prevention.
results_summary: Participants in the walking and walking/nutrition groups showed significant improvements in skeletal muscle mass index (SMI), IGF-1, and 25(OH)D levels compared to controls, with additional DHEA-S improvements in the walking/nutrition group, particularly in frail individuals.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older in Japan.
effective_dosage: Pedometer-based walking program (specific steps not detailed) and nutritional supplementation (details not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a group education program to promote walking in people with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The intervention group showed superior walking capacity and quality of life compared to controls, with significant improvements in six-minute walk distance, treadmill maximum walking distance, and ICQ scores. Daily step counts did not differ between groups, and exit interviews indicated the program was well-received and increased participants' understanding of their condition and walking habits.
population_specificity: People with intermittent claudication (Rutherford category 1-3).
effective_dosage: Three-hour group-based education workshop plus follow-up telephone support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical value of the six-minute walking test as an assessment tool for patients with interstitial lung disease.
results_summary: The study confirmed the clinical value of the six-minute walking test as an important addition to traditional lung function assessments, aiding in diagnosis, treatment response analysis, and prognosis.
population_specificity: Patients suspected of having interstitial lung disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare trunk muscle activity and lumbar spine range of motion during gait while wearing unstable shoes versus conventional stable shoes.
results_summary: Unstable shoes significantly increased erector spinae and rectus abdominis muscle activity and lumbar spine extension during gait compared to control shoes.
population_specificity: 48 healthy voluntary participants (average age 24.5±5.6 years, BMI 22.7±6.8 kg/m2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of accelerometry for monitoring physical activity, including walking, in mechanically ventilated adult ICU patients.
results_summary: Accelerometry correlated well with direct observation in reporting the frequency and duration of physical activities like walking but could not differentiate activity intensity or voluntary vs. involuntary movements. It may serve as a useful adjunct but requires additional objective data for accurate activity recording.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated adult ICU patients with poor functional mobility.

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare the efficacy of topical platelet-derived growth factor versus placebo in treating diabetic foot ulcers, with both groups using a short leg walking cast for offloading.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in healing rates between the test and control groups (52% vs. 57%). Overall, 74% of subjects healed by 9 months with casting alone, though larger initial wound size and excessive drainage were associated with slower healing.
population_specificity: Subjects with Wagner grade I diabetic foot ulcers (1 cm² to 16 cm²), without severe peripheral arterial disease, osteomyelitis, or infections requiring antibiotics.
effective_dosage: Study medication (topical platelet-derived growth factor or placebo) was applied daily.
study_duration: Up to 4 months (with some subjects continuing casts beyond this period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the medium-term effectiveness and safety of endobronchial coils in reducing hyperinflation and improving quality of life in patients with severe emphysema.
results_summary: At 360 days post-treatment, coil therapy significantly improved quality of life (SGRQ score), pulmonary function (FEV1), and exercise capacity (6-minute walking distance). The safety profile was deemed acceptable.
population_specificity: Patients with severe emphysema, hyperinflation, and airflow obstruction.
effective_dosage: Bilateral sequential treatment with coils (30-day interval between treatments).
study_duration: 360 days (12 months) follow-up after final treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (BLVR) using a one-way endobronchial valve for severe emphysema patients, including its impact on walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that BLVR improved six-minute walking distance and other measures like FEV1 and cycle workload in severe emphysema patients, particularly those with complete fissures. However, no significant changes were observed in patients with incomplete fissures.
population_specificity: Severe COPD patients with emphysema

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of Integral-based hatha yoga on physical and psychological health in sedentary individuals with arthritis.
results_summary: Yoga significantly improved physical health, walking capacity, mood, and quality of life at 8 weeks, with sustained benefits observed at 9 months. No adverse events were associated with yoga.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults aged 18+ with rheumatoid arthritis or knee osteoarthritis (mostly female, white, college-educated).
effective_dosage: Two 60-minute yoga classes and one home practice per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess ground-based walking activity in ICU survivors within 1 week of discharge and evaluate the feasibility and safety of the Six-Minute Walk Test (6MWT) for this population.
results_summary: Participants ambulated at a low percentage (29%) of their measured exercise capacity (6MWD). The 6MWT was found to be safe, with only 22% experiencing transient oxygen desaturation that resolved quickly.
population_specificity: Inpatients recovering from critical illness (ICU survivors; mean age 57 years, median ICU stay 11 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the associations between mobility (assessed via walking performance) and factors like sleep patterns, physical activity, and physical symptoms in older Koreans with chronic illnesses.
results_summary: The study found that over 90% of participants had impaired mobility (below 400 meters in the 6MWT), with mobility declining with age. Significant predictors of better mobility included younger age, regular physical activity, female gender, higher income, and better sleep perception.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older Koreans (aged 60s-80s) with chronic illnesses.
study_duration: Data collected from July to December 2012 (no specific intervention duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine differences in knee kinematics (tibial rotation and knee flexion angles) between the meniscectomized and contralateral limbs during static and dynamic activities, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that the meniscectomized limb exhibited more external tibial rotation and greater knee flexion at initial contact compared to the contralateral limb during walking, with these differences increasing with activity demand.
population_specificity: Thirteen patients (2 female) who underwent unilateral, arthroscopic, partial medial meniscectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how FitFlop™ footwear affects lower extremity joint moments, kinematics, and center of pressure profiles during walking compared to conventional sandals and athletic trainers.
results_summary: FitFlop™ significantly altered gait patterns, including anterior displacement of the center of pressure, reduced ankle joint range of motion, and changes in peak hip extensor and plantarflexor moments compared to other footwear.
population_specificity: 28 healthy participants
study_duration: Not specified (5 walking trials per condition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if delayed motor skill milestones (sitting, standing, walking) could serve as an early screening tool for autism spectrum disorder.
results_summary: The study found that children with autism had significantly delayed acquisition of motor skills (sitting, standing, walking) compared to WHO standards, suggesting these milestones could be used for early screening.
population_specificity: 124 children with autism spectrum disorder (male and female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the physiological stimulus and perceived exertion of walking and running on a non-motorized curved treadmill (NMCT) versus a standard motorized treadmill (SMT).
results_summary: The study found that NMCT elicited significantly greater intensity (measured in METs) and higher perceived exertion (RPE) for both walking and running compared to SMT. Participants also preferred slower speeds on NMCT for easy and moderate intensity training.
population_specificity: 10 healthy athletic adults
effective_dosage: Walking at 1.34 m/s for 3 minutes, running at 2.24 m/s for 4 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy and comparative effectiveness of surgery (including decompression plus fusion and interspinous process spacer devices) in managing lumbar spinal stenosis, with walking ability as one of the primary outcome measures.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking ability between decompression plus fusion and decompression alone (risk ratio 0.9, 95% CI 0.4 to 1.9). Interspinous process spacer devices showed slightly better outcomes for disability but had higher reoperation rates compared to decompression alone.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a prevention program based on the Health Belief Model, including walking, on osteoporosis in women.
results_summary: The study found that walking, combined with dietary changes and education, significantly improved bone mineral density (BMD) in the lumbar spine and hip compared to the control group. These effects were sustained six months after the intervention.
population_specificity: Women registered under health centers in Fasa City, Fars Province, Iran (60 cases, 60 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a community-based walking intervention (WYHH) in promoting physical activity and reducing cardiovascular risk among non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic residents in Detroit.
results_summary: The intervention group significantly increased step counts during the initial 8-week period, with associated reductions in systolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol, waist circumference, and body mass index, which were maintained at 32 weeks.
population_specificity: Non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic residents of Detroit, Michigan, in a low-to-moderate income urban community.
effective_dosage: Walking groups met three times per week for 45 to 90 minutes (duration increased over time).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an intra-articular corticosteroid injection before exercise therapy provided additional clinical benefits for pain and function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain improvement between the corticosteroid and placebo groups after a 12-week exercise program, suggesting no additional benefit from the injection. Secondary outcomes also showed no statistically significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with radiographic confirmation of knee osteoarthritis, localized inflammation, and knee pain during walking (pain score >4 on a 0-10 scale).
effective_dosage: 1-mL injection of methylprednisolone acetate (40 mg/mL) dissolved in 4 mL of lidocaine hydrochloride (10 mg/mL) for the corticosteroid group; 1-mL isotonic saline mixed with 4 mL of lidocaine hydrochloride (10 mg/mL) for the placebo group.
study_duration: 12-week supervised exercise program following a single injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of deep fibular nerve neurotomy for treating extension dystonia of the hallux and/or other toes in neurological patients.
results_summary: Dystonia disappeared in 75% of cases, with minimal persistence in others. Patients reported significant pain reduction, fewer difficulties with footwear, and high satisfaction (8.5/10). Adverse effects were rare and transient.
population_specificity: Adult neurological patients with extension dystonia of the hallux and/or other toes (n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the management of pregnancy-related pubic symphysis separation, including the role of walking in symptom presentation and recovery.
results_summary: The study found that pain on movement, especially walking or climbing stairs, is often present in cases of postpartum symphyseal rupture. Conservative treatments, including physiotherapy, are successful in most cases, with symptom reduction typically occurring within 6 weeks but sometimes taking up to 6 months.
population_specificity: Postpartum women with pubic symphysis separation or dysfunction.
study_duration: Symptom reduction observed within 6 weeks to 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of daily walking on office, home, and 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: Daily walking significantly reduced office, home, and 24-hour blood pressure, as well as improved 24-hour heart rate and lipid metabolism, though the BP changes were modest. The study concluded that walking may have limited value as a non-pharmacologic therapy for hypertension due to small BP reductions.
population_specificity: 65 treated or untreated patients with essential hypertension (39 women and 26 men, average age 60 ± 9 years).
effective_dosage: 30-60 minutes of daily walking to achieve 10,000 steps per day.
study_duration: 4 weeks of walking intervention followed by 4 weeks of usual activities (randomized cross-over design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether riociguat improved responder thresholds (e.g., 6MWD, functional class, hemodynamic measures) in patients with inoperable chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension or persistent/recurrent pulmonary hypertension after pulmonary endarterectomy.
results_summary: Riociguat significantly increased the proportion of patients achieving positive response criteria (e.g., 6MWD ≥380 m, functional class I/II, reduced pulmonary vascular resistance) compared to placebo, with minimal changes observed in the placebo group. Similar improvements were noted for other hemodynamic and biomarker thresholds.
population_specificity: Patients with inoperable chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension or persistent/recurrent pulmonary hypertension after pulmonary endarterectomy.
effective_dosage: Individually adjusted up to 2.5 mg three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an Internet-mediated, pedometer-based walking program could improve health-related quality of life and daily step counts in veterans with COPD.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in Symptoms and Impact domains of HRQL and walked 779 more steps per day compared to controls, though no significant difference was found in the Activities domain or overall SGRQ-TS.
population_specificity: Veterans with COPD (mean age 67 ± 9 years, 94% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pelvis acceleration-derived parameters could differentiate between dynamic stability states for transtibial amputees during level and uneven ground walking and correlate these parameters with clinical balance and mobility measures.
results_summary: Seven of 26 pelvis acceleration measures significantly differed between level and uneven ground walking, with medial-lateral acceleration range being the most frequent predictor in regression models. Uneven ground walking provided the most relevant data for balance and mobility assessment, explaining up to 100% of variability in clinical measures.
population_specificity: Eleven individuals with unilateral transtibial amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cardiometabolic effects of Nordic Walking and Pilates on postmenopausal women, focusing on changes in body weight, blood glucose, and lipid levels.
results_summary: Nordic Walking resulted in significant improvements in body weight, BMI, blood glucose, and lipid profiles, with greater efficacy than Pilates. Both exercise groups showed favorable changes, while the control group exhibited no significant improvements.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese postmenopausal women (n=196, with 147 completing the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and effectiveness of unsupervised home-based robotic locomotion training (MoreGait) for improving walking function in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking velocity and endurance, with 9 out of 25 participants reducing dependency on walking aids. Only one device-related adverse event (a pressure sore) occurred in over 800 training sessions.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (5 tetraplegia, 20 paraplegia; 7 AIS C, 18 AIS D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 45 minutes of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation before exercise could delay pain onset and increase walking distance in peripheral artery disease patients.
results_summary: Total walking distance significantly differed between stimulation conditions (10 Hz, 80 Hz, sham, and control), with 10 Hz being the most effective. No differences were observed in heart rate or blood pressure across conditions.
population_specificity: 15 patients with class II peripheral artery disease
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (10 Hz or 80 Hz)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of strengthening exercises versus proprioceptive-balance exercises on lower extremity function, including walking, in patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that proprioceptive-balance exercises significantly improved walking, stair climbing, and balance more than strengthening exercises in patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Both exercise types showed improvements, but balance exercises were more effective overall.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess postoperative motor disability and the effectiveness of customized rehabilitation in recovering walking capacity and postural changes in cardiothoracic surgery patients.
results_summary: Most patients (74.45% in cardiac surgery, 94.73% in thoracic surgery) recovered independent walking ability after rehabilitation. The majority were transferred to intensive rehabilitation or returned home post-discharge, indicating successful recovery.
population_specificity: 417 inpatients who underwent cardiothoracic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of peri-infarct pacing on preventing adverse post-MI remodeling, including changes in 6-minute walking distance as a secondary outcome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking; it only mentions 6-minute walking distance as a secondary objective to be assessed.
population_specificity: Patients with large myocardial infarction (peak creatine phosphokinase >3,000 U/L or troponin T >10 μg/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-intensity walking improves glucose control in individuals with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and if these improvements correlate with changes in skeletal muscle gene expression.
results_summary: Walking improved waist circumference and work capacity in individuals who achieved normal glucose tolerance (NGT) post-intervention, along with increased mRNA expression of mitochondrial markers. However, those with more severe glycemic derangement showed limited improvements.
population_specificity: Overweight individuals with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT)
effective_dosage: Low-intensity unsupervised walking (specific frequency/duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether integrating low-to-moderate intensity physical activity (walking) with smoking cessation counseling could reduce short-term smoking cue reactivity and improve quit rates among low-income sedentary smokers.
results_summary: The study proposed an intervention (Step-Up to Quit) that combined walking (7500-10,000 steps/day) with smoking cessation counseling, focusing on using short bouts of walking to manage smoking urges. Results on cue reactivity and quit rates were pending at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Low-income, sedentary adults who smoke more than 6 cigarettes per day.
